processedArray.text: Write a program that prints the number of tires on 767 cars.  For this exercise let's assume that all cars have 4 tires.To arrive at this result, we will have to create an expression that starts with the number of cars and multiples it by the number of tires on each car.

Write a program that prints the length (in feet) of each part of a 10 foot board that is sawn into 7 equal parts ( 10 divided by 7 ).As we have been doing, we must write an expression that will evaluate to the result we need, and we will put thatexpression inside the parentheses of an alert statement to get it evaluated and printed out.  In this problem, the 
expression involves number data.

Write a program that prints the words "space" and "craft" with a hyphen between.  Use string concatenation to do this.  Concatenation of strings is done with the + operator.As before, we will create an expression to put inside the the parentheses of an alert statement
to get it evaluated and printed.
The expression will concatenate the 3 strings together.

Write a program that prints out the roots of the quadratic equation  for the specific case of a:2, b:10, and c:-100. Do this with two separate alert statements, each printing a single number. Roots of the quadratic equations are computed with these expressions: -b  +/-  square root of ( b^2 - 4ac )  
---------------------------------------------
                      2a  
the +/- means do one computation with  + and then another with  -.
Square roots can be computed with the Math.sqrt function.  This complicated expression will show you the value of using parentheses to make your intentions unambiguous. 
Alert the "+" root first, then alert the "-" root with a separate alert statement.

Write a program that creates a variable "profName".  Then assign my name to it, and print out the value of the variable.  For reference, my name is spelled Stotts .This program will be very similar to the previous one.
The difference is we are here storing string data into the variable (rather than number data).
Any type of data can be stored in a JavaScript variable.  You can, for example, store a number into a variable and
then later in the program execution store a string or a boolean into the same variable.

Write this program by modifying your previous program. Using the variable "profAge" you made earlier, print out how many months old I am.  All we need to see is the number of months. 
This program will show that more complicated expressions can contain variable names as well at constant data values. In your program, you will create an expression in your alert statement where you multiply by 12 the value stored in variable profAge. To evaluate the expression, JavaScript will retrieve the 
data stored in "profAge" first, then combine that data with the 12 using the multiplication operator. 
Remember that you can reload your previous program by clicking on the previous problem, and clicking the "Reload Last" dark blue button above the editor window.

Build this program by modifying the previous one. Use the variable "profAge" , and the computation of my age in months, and this time add anexplanatory message to the output along with the number.
The format for the output is this: 
  My prof is 348 months old.
Note the blanks before and after the 348, and the period at the end.  You will also produce the printed sentence by using the variable profAge and multiplying it in the alert.  In other words, you will compute 348 (as in the previous problem) in order to have that value appear in output.

Write a program that will compute the area of a circle with radius 5.25 units. Print out the result in the format show below.In your program, first create a variable "pi" and assign to it the value of pi to 5 decimal places (3.14159). Create another variable named "radius" and assign to it the value 5.25. Now using variables "pi" and "radius" compute the area of a circle and assign that to a new variable "area" ( area is pi * radius * radius ). 
In this program, we learn how to mix variables with strings using concatenation to make readable and explanatory output.
You must print out the value "area" embedded in a message explaining it. 
The final output will look this way: 
  Area of a circle with radius 5.25 units is 86.590074375 units squared
with no period at the end.  The numbers in the output must be computed by expressions using the variables.

Write a program that will compute the circumference of a circle with radius 5.25 units. Print out the result in the format show below.The formula for circumference is pi * radius * 2 . For pi use 3.14159.  You can build this program by modifying the Area of a circle program.
 
The output should look like this: 
  A circle with radius 5.25 units has a circumference that is 32.986695 units.

Write a program that prints out the roots of the quadratic equation  for the specific case of a:2, b:10, and c:-100. Do this with two separate alert statements, each printing a single number. Let's revisit the quadratic equation, but this time use variables to make the code easier to write and to understand.Start with the program you wrote for the Quadratic equation problem in the Expressions module.
Declare variables "a", "b", and "c". Give a the value 2, b the value 10, and c the value -100. Compute the two roots of the quadratic equation but use the variable names a, b, and c in the expressions. Assign one root to a variable "root1"; assign the other root to the variable "root2". Print out the two root variables using two separate alert statements.  Print the "+" root first, and then print the "-" root.  
For reference, the roots of the quadratic equations are  -b +/- square root of ( b^2 - 4ac )  all over 2a , and you can use Math.sqrt() to compute the square root.

A parking lot has 53 cars in it (each with 4 wheels) and 17 trucks (each with 6 wheels).  Write a program that prints out the total number of wheels in that parking lot.  Use a single alert statement with an expression to produce the correct number by multiplying and adding appropriately.

A chocolate cake weighs 7 pounds.  It is cut into 13 equal pieces.  Write a program that will print out the weight (in pounds) of 3 pieces of cake.Use a single alert statement to do this, and use an expression to compute the correct number by diving and multiplying appropriately.

Write a program that will print out the length of the hypotenuse of a right triangle with side lengths 3 and 7.  Use a single alert statement and write an expression that computes the correct number by multiplying, adding, and square rooting appropriately.  
The Pythagorean theorem is used (among other things) to compute the length of the hypotenuse of a right triangle, given the lengths of its two shorter sides.  The equation is 
   a^2 + b^2 = h^2 

      where h is the hypotenuse.  If we do a little algebra, we get 

   h = square root of ( a^2 + b^2 )
Like we did in the Quadratic equation program, use Math.sqrt ( ) to find the square root.

Write a program that asks the user for a number, then computes and prints out the square root of that input. 
 Use the myMain format you learned in the previous problems.  To do this, the body of the myMain function will call another function: the Math.sqrt() function that is pre-defined for you in JavaScript. It will also be calling the function "prompt" to get input, and the function "alert" to produce output.
Functions can call other functions.  This is how smaller chunks of code organized as function definitions can be made to execute together as if they were a larger single program.
We term the order in which statements are executed in a program the "control flow".  Calling a function, and returning values, is an important
kind of control flow that we will need to carefully understand.  When a function is executing (let's say myMain() for example), 
the code for the function body will run statement by statement from the beginning of the body.  When a call to another function 
(let's say Math.sqrt for example) is encountered in myMain's body, the execution of myMain will pause... it will stop executing while Math.sqrt
begins to run.  Eventually Math.sqrt computes a value, and it stops executing; it sends that value back to myMain, and myMain begins executing
again at the point where Math.sqrt was called.  The value sent back in put in place of the call so myMain can continue.  We say that (in this
example) myMain is the "calling" function, and Math.sqrt is the "called" function.
We will see this control flow illustrated in the Memory Map chalk talks that are coming up in the next module.  We will also see how variables
are laid out in memory and how execution causes those values to change.

Write a program that computes the number of ounces in 3.14 gallons.To get the result, we will produce an expression and save the evaluated value in a variable; we will use the facts that a gallon has 4 quarts, a quart has 32 ounces.   
Print out the results in a phrase (string) like this:
In 3.14 gallons there are 401.92 ounces
 
(with no period at the end, and no blanks before the first "In" and no blanks after the ending "ces"). You will use string concatenation ( + ) to glue all the text strings and number expressions together inside an alert statement.

Write a program that takes the string "one" the string "two" and the string "three" and prints out all of them concatenated with commas between. Use the "+" string operator to do this. The result will be the string "one,two,three" .

Comparisons 
Now we return to study Boolean data in more detail.
One of the main uses for Boolean (true, false) data is to answer questions like "is the value in this variable larger than the value stored in this other variable?".
If we can get answers to questions like this we can make decisions that affect the control flow of our programs, and the final outcomes of them.
We ask questions like this using comparison operators (less than, equal to, greater than, etc.).  An expression using comparison operators
will "answer" the question by producing a boolean result (true, or false).
To complete this problem, type in this JavaScript program:
&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp alert( 100 &nbsp&nbsp&nbsp alert( 100 === 200 );
There are several ways you can interpret a boolean expression.  Consider the first expression here... 100 So we expect the first expression to evaluate to true, since 100 is less than 200.
We expect the second expression to evaluate to false, since it is not the case that 100 is the same numerical value as 200.
Remember to use the myMain function format for style points.

Write a program that will print out the length of the hypotenuse of a right triangle with side lengths 3 and 7.  In this problem we revisit the Pythagorean theorem: a^2 + b^2 = h^2.  As before we need to compute the square root of the sum of the squares of the shorter sides of an right triangle.  This time we will declare three variables a, b, and c.  Assign the value 3 to a; assign the value 7 to b.  Then write an expression using variables a and b that will produce the length of the hypotenuse and assign that value to h.  Print out the value of h (just the number). 
We need a single alert statement, and that statement will simply print the value of the variable h after you have computed and stored into h the
proper result.

Let's do the quadratic equation program yet again again, this time in our new myMain format. 
Yes, yet again.  Whatever else you learn in this course, you will remember the quadratic equation :) .
Take the program you wrote for Quadratic 3 (in folder "Input") and put it into proper myMain function format.  
It will behave the same as before, it will just be structured differently.  The user will still be giving values for a, b, and c as 
prompt input.
Testing notes: Obviously, since we knows what results to expect, try running your program and giving the inputs
a as 2, b as 10, and c as -100.  Try some other values as well... google up some solutions to the quadratic equations and see that
your code gives those answers.  In testing any program, we will always have the issue of an "oracle" -- we will need something that
tells us what output to expect from a correct program.  We will design a set of test cases... inputs that exercise the full range of input
values that the program is built to handle, matched with the proper output for each input.

Write a program that will print out the length of the hypotenuse of a right triangle with side lengths given by the user as input from the keyboard.  
Yet again.  Take the program you wrote for Pythagoras 3 (in folder "Input") and put it into proper myMain function format. 
It will behave the same: it will be getting values of a and b from the user via prompts.  The only change will be in structural style.

Write a program that will find roots for the quadratic equation, and make it do that solving twice. 
Take the code you just wrote for Quadratic 4 as a starting point for this problem.  Modify your code to simply run the function twice.  We will define the function once (as we did before), but we will run that function twice by putting two calls to myMain() at the end, one after the other.  This will cause the code that performs the Quadratic equation computation to execute, and then execute a second time right after the first. 
Notice:this violates our format rules  (which call for a single function call to myMain() at the end) but for this problem the violation is ok... we are learning the point that you can call a function as many times as you like, but you declare (define) it only once..

Let's do a problem using what we have learned (up through simple functions).  Get 5 numbers from the user.  Compute and print (in this order) these things (each a separate alert statement):
the sum of the 5 numbersthe average of the 5 numbersthe largest of the 5 numbersthe smallest of the 5 numbersthe largest number divided by the smallest, truncated to 2 decimal places (USE Math.floor. DO NOT use Math.trunc)To do this before we have learned conditional statements you will need the Math.max() function.
If you call Math.max(a,b) it will return the larger value.  Math.max() can take many arguments; for example, Math.max(a,b,c) will return the largest of the three values stored in variables a, b, and c.  There is a corresponding Math.min() function to use for finding the smallest.
Output format: Let's say the user gives these numbers: 6, 3, 11, 17, 4. Then the output should look this way (Each line is an alert, and pay attention to blanks etc.):
   sum: 41
   average: 8.2
   max: 17
   min: 3
   ratio: 5.66
Remember to put your program in proper myMain function format.

Write a program that will convert a person's height from feet and inches into centimeters.  Print out the centimeter height as a single number. 
Let's revisit the "User height in cm" problem from module "Input".  Write a program that will functionally do the same thing, but is in proper myMain function format.

Write a program to get two numbers from the user, and print out the answer to this question: Is the first number given greater than the second number given?
 
The lesson to learn here is that an expression using a comparison operator "turns into" a true or a false when it is evaluated.
Remember to use the proper myMain function style.

Write a program to get two numbers from the user, and print out the answer to this question: Is the first number given less than or equal to the second number given?
 
Here the operator we are working with is "less that or equal to".  It will be written as "

Write a program to get two strings from the user (no call to Number() around the prompt), and print out the answer to this question: Is the first string the same as the second string given?
 
Here we are learning that comparison operators work for string data as well as number data.  The only question is: what does it mean for two strings to be equal?
Similarly, we will need to know how to decide if one string is less than another (and greater than).
When comparing strings we use alphabetic order (dictionary order) to answer questions of less than or greater than.  If a string S comes before a string T in the dictionary, then we say that S =,  >,  ===, !== ) on strings and see how they behave.  See if upper case characters come before lower, for example.
See where special characters like +, !, #, : etc. come compared to alphabetic characters.  Where do the digits 0-9 fit in?

Write a program to get two numbers from the user and print out the answer to this question: Is the first number given different from the second number given?
 
To answer "different from" we will use the "not equals" operator, written " !== ".  The ! is used in many programming languages to mean "not",
and in JavaScript it is an operator all by itself (the logical NOT operator).  Putting it in front of the == makes the not equals operator.
It may be obvious, but two numbers (and two strings) are not equal if the === question (equality) would be answered false.  
 if ( S1 === S2 ) is false, then (S1 !== S2 ) is true
The opposing senses that happen when
using not on boolean can take some getting used to.

Write a program to get two strings from the user and print out the answer to this question: Does the first string come before the second string in alphabetic order?
 
We will use the less than operator to answer this question.  Comparing strings for less than (or greater than) uses alphabetic order to make the decision.
If string S1 appears in a dictionary before another string S2, then we say that S1 Just like in a dictionary, if one string is a proper prefix of another, then the shorter word precedes.  For example, "tar" There is one further warning about strings made up of digits (that look like numbers).  This issue illustrates why we must be careful to convert
keyboard input to numeric data if the user is trying to input numbers.
Consider this:  is "450"

Repetition: Loops 
Loops give us major problem solving power.  Without them programs would be useful for solving only small problems, like we have been doing.  Loops allow us to write a finite number of statements but to have them executed many many (possibly infinite) times, by repeating at run-time rather than at write-time.  
A "for loop" is designed to be used when we know we need to repeat a block of statements a specific number of times.  We call this definite looping; we know when we write the code how many times to repeat.
We designate the code block to repeat, and we specify a variable to count the repetitions (called the loop index); we give that variable a starting value (often 0); we write a boolean comparison expression to answer the question "do we repeat again?", and we write an expression telling how to change the value of the index at the end of each repetition (often increment by 1).
To complete this problem, type in this JavaScript program (in proper myMain format):
  for ( var i=0;  iHow many times will the alert statement get executed?

Write a program that will print out the sum of the integers from 1 to 99, including 1 and 99.  
We will use a for loop to do this.
You will also need an "accumulator", a variable that has its value bumped up each time you go through the loop body.
Since we are summing, the accumulator will be initialized to 0 (the additive identity) outside the loop.  With a counter, the variable is bumped by some
fixed amount (often 1).  With an accumulator, the variable is bumped up by perhaps different amounts each time it is increased.
Think of an accumulator as a bucket.  We will accumulate a final value by adding into the bucket parts of the final amount, many times.
Lesson here: the loop index is a variable that can be used inside the loop body; it is often used to generate a sequence of numbers, or to count how many times the loop body has run.
Style: Use one for loop and no other loops.

Write a program that will request the user to input 5 numbers (one per prompt) and print the average of the inputs. 
Do this by creating a for loop that will run 5 times, and put a prompt statement inside the loop body.
Every time the user inputs a number (remember to make it a Number() ) add it into an accumulator.  When the loop is done, compute the average (outside and after the for loop).
For output, just alert the number that is the average.
Since we are summing, the accumulator will be initialized to 0 before the loop.
Style: Use one for loop and no other loops.

Write a program that will print out the first 5 positive integers (one per alert).   
To do this we set up a for loop and use the loop index as a variable that will contain the numbers in this sequence successively as we repeat the loop body.  
This means one good use for a for loop is to generate a sequence of numbers.
Start the loop index at 1, end it when we have done the 5th body execution; we bump up the value of the loop index by 1 each time we loop.
Inside the loop body we simply alert the value of the loop index variable.  Since we start the index at 1, the first time the body executes we will get the 1 in the number sequence.  Since we increment the index by one, we will get a 2 the next time we do the loop body... and then 3, ... and so on.
The lesson we want to learn in this program is: the loop index (the loop control variable) is a variable like any other in your program,
and it's value can be accessed inside the loop body.  This is a very helpful feature for solving problems.
Style: Use one for loop and no other loops.

Compute and print out the sum of all the odd integers from 17 to 204. 
Use only one for loop and no other loops.
The lesson in this program is that the for loop index variable does not always have to be incremented by 1.
If we want to increment it by 2, or 5, or 10, or whatever we can specify that in the loop control information.
To generate odd numbers, then, we could start the loop index at 1, and increment it by 2 each time the loop 
body executes.  This would create the sequence of values 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, etc. in the loop index variable.

Compute and print out the product of all the even integers from 4 to 16. 
Use one for loop and no other loops.
The lesson we are learning in this program is that an accumulator can accumulate by multiplication also.
The previous accumulator was being increased by addition, so we started it with the value of 0.
In this program, since we will be accumulating by multiplying we will initialize the accumulator variable to 1 (the multiplicative identity for numbers).

Write a program that will prompt the user for a positive integer, and then print out the factorial of that number. 
You can Google it if you need more detail, but factorial of N is defined as the product of all integers from 1 to N.  In math notation, N factorial is written " N! " .
Here the ! is not to be confused with the logical NOT operator... it is a different thing in this context.
Later (soon later) we will worry about the fact that users are not perfect and might give erroneous data (like a negative number); for now let's continue to assume users make no mistakes.  
Style: Use one for loop and no other loops.
A brief math note is warranted here.  Factorial is a function that grows very rapidly.  Due to the limitations of Javascript, you will not be able to compute the factorial for integers that are larger than some value.  On my computer at this writing, the limit is about 170.  These factorial values quickly become unimaginably huge.  
For example, 5! is 120, but 20! is more than a trillion millions.  
The number of different shuffles possible in a deck of 52 cards is 52!, and this number is larger than the number of atoms in the known universe.
Once you blow out Javascript's ability to maintain numerical precision properly, it will simply report "Infinity" as a result.  This really means "oops... its just a really big number I can't properly deal with."  So try running your program with different larger input numbers and see for yourself where the limits are for your Javascript on your computer.
So, in practical terms, your program asks the user for a positive integer as input, but we secretly hope the user gives us a small positive integer.

Write a program that will prompt the user for a positive integer, and then produce output that looks like this:body: 0
body: 1
body: 2
 . . .
body: N-1
where N is the number the user gave.
 
For example, if the user gives number 4 as input, then the program produces 4 lines of output, with the lines numbered 0 through 3.
It's no secret you will do this with a for loop. Each time the body executes it will print out (alert) the message "body:  " followed by the appropriate
integer.  You should use the loop index variable as your body execution counter. The main issue is to get the start/stop/increment loop parameters set up 
to count properly.
Style: Use one for loop, and no other loops.

Write a program that will print the square root of each integer between 99 and 104 (inclusive). Print the square roots truncated to 3 decimal places. 
Use one for loop and no other loops.  Output should be only numbers (no string data explaining the numbers).  Print one square root per alert statement, so your output will be 
6 numbers, one per alert.

Write a program that will print the first 10 powers of 2, starting with 2^1. 
Do not use the Math.pow function.  Instead, use the
loop index tp count body executions (you will do 10 of those), and use an accumulator to build the powers you need at each step.
We can start the accumulator at 2 (2^1).  After printing the value in the accumulator in the loop body, we double the value stored in 
the accumulator (we multiply it's value by 2).  When we are done, the accumulator will have accumulated the value 2^10, but along the way
in each loop iteration it will have accumulated 2^1, 2^2, 2^3, ... 2^i  (for the ith iteration), etc.
Another way to do this is use the loop index as an accumulator, but this is a bit more obscure.
Start the loop index at 2, and then when it is time to increment the index, instead of the common i++ (increment by 1) we
can double the loop index ( i *= 2 ).  The 
lesson here is that the loop index does not have to be incremented by 1... it can be changed in any way you need it to be.
So loop index starts at 2 (and gets printed).  It then becomes 2*2, and then (2*2)*2... and so forth.
Doing the problem this way, the loop has to end when it goes past 2^10.
By the way, 2^10 is 1024.  This is the value we means in "computer speak" when we say 1K.  The K means roughly 1000,
but really is 2 to the 10th power.  We do everything in binary (base 2).
Output: Your output should be numbers only, no string data explaining the numbers.  You will have 10 numbers, one per alert.
Style: Use one for loop and no other loops.

Write a program that will prompt the user for a number; if that number is greater than 100 print out "over 100".  Then print "done" no matter whatnumber the user gives.
 
The "if-then" conditional statement is the simplest one we have in Javascript.  
The syntax of an if-then specifies a condition (a boolean comparison) and a one code block (a sequence of statements inside curly braces).
The flow of control it creates can be thought of as 
"based on the truth of the condition, we will either execute the code block, or we will skip it"For this program, note that we are still counting on our users to be nice and error-free when typing in input value.
Prompt the user for a number and store it in a variable.
That variable will be the one used in the boolean comparison used in the conditional statement.
Try testing the program with inputs 152 and 30.
Style: do this program using one simple if-then statement (no else part).

Write the following program: first, prompt the user for a number; print out "100 or over" if the user gave a number that is greater than or equal to 100;if the number is less than 100, print out "under 100" and then print the number divided by 8 (two separate alerts);
either way, the last thing to do is print out "done" and end.
 
The "if-then-else" conditional statement specifies a conditional (boolean comparison expression), 
and two code blocks (call them the "then-block", and the "else-block").  
The flow of control allows us to execute either one block, or the other, but not both.  
We will execute one of them, and skip the other, based on the answer we get from the question posed in the condition.
If the condition evaluates to true, the then-block executes and the else-block is skipped.  If the condition evaluates to false,
the opposite happens -- we skip the then-block and execute the else-block.
Either way, we continue program execution with the statement that follows the entire if-then-else statement.
Style: do this problem with one if-then-else statement.  Try testing the code with 153, and then test again with -88.
Test with 100 as well, to make sure you got the boundary conditions correct.

Write a program that asks the user to input a number between 0 and 100 inclusive; if the user gave something that is not a number, print "error" and end the program. If the number is less than 0, print "negative" and end execution; if the number is greater than 100 print "over 100" and end. 
If all validations pass, print the user's number divided by 8, truncated to 3 decimal places.
 
We are now adding validation checks to see if the input is a number, as opposed to something else ( like text, or numeric error ).  
You will find the function isNaN() useful here.  This function returns true if the argument given is... NOT a number (a string, or some other value like NaN or null).  It returns false if the argument IS a number.  This "backwards" sense can be tricky to think it out clearly.
In summary, this program is first doing validation checks to make sure we get a number.  Once we are sure its a number, we do validation checks to make sure the number
fits in the needed range.  Once we are sure we have a "good" number, we get on with the actual computation.  In this case the actual computation is nothing much
because the goal it to understand the validation checks.

Write a program that will get from the user a positive integer not greater than 120.  Validate the input;  if any validation fails, simply print "bad" and quit executing. Finally, if all validations pass, then print out the factorial of the number.
 
Now we will add some format checking to our validations.  We will be checking to see if a number is as integer (along with the other checks). 
We will build on the previous factorial program (in module "for loops") by adding to it input validation.
We are prompting the user for a positive integer not greater than 120. We now have several things to check... is it numeric? is it in the right range? is it an integer?  The integer check is the new lesson in this program.
Validate the input first to make sure it looks like a number (not a string like "tarheels").  We saw how to do this in a previous program.  
Then, as before, convert it to internal numeric form, and make sure it is greater than 0 and less than or equal to 120.
Finally, validate it to make sure it is an integer.  If any validation fails, we simply print "bad"  and quit executing. 
To test a number to see if it is an integer, you can use modular arithmetic (the % operator).  If N is an integer, then
(N%1) will be 0.  This says if we divide the number by 1, there is no remainder.  For example if we divide 6 by 1 it goes 6 times evenly.
In contrast, if we divide 14.3 by 1 it goes 14 times and the remainder is 0.3, so 14.3 it is not an integer.
Another way to test a positive number N for being an integer is to compare N to Math.floor(N).  If N is an integer these will be equal.  For example let N be 7.3 which makes Math.floor(N) be 7.  These are not the same so 7.3 is not an integer (note, this method only works for positive numbers). Use whichever method you like for this program, since we are making sure the user gives positive numbers.

Write a program that will decide the level of violation a person will be charged with when caught speeding. Get the user to input a number 0 or greater (the speed).  The input does not have to be an integer.  If the number is over 100, print "insane". If the number is greater than 80 but 100 or less, print "reckless". If the number is greater than 65 but 80 or less, print "excessive". If the number is 65 or under, print "legal".  
We have seen that the if-then-else conditional statement allows us to do one of two alternate blocks of code (and skip the other).
This can be generalized to create several blocks of code, and select one of them to execute (and all others skipped).  To do this, we
chain if-then-else statements together one after another in a "cascade".  
We will use this conditional structure when we have 3, 4, 5 or more different data situations to detect and something to do for each situation, as in the program here.
Try testing the program with inputs 25, 65, 66, 80, 81, 100, 121, and 0.
Style: do this using one cascading conditional statement, of the form if-then-else where the else part is another if-then-else.

Let's revisit the speed violation problem we did in a prior folder.  Add some input data validation to make the program more robust. Follow the specifications following.  
The problem we will build on is "If then else if else (cascade)" in module "Conditionals".

Repetition: While Loops 
A second type of loop statement in JavaScript is the while loop.  
A while loop is less rigidly structured than a for loop; 
in a while loop we have to manually set up and maintain any loop index variables, counters, etc. we might need as part of the code in the loop body.
We use while loops primarily for what we call indefinite looping, where we do
not know (when we write the code) how many times the loop body will need to execute.  
It should be noted that these loop forms (for, while) are notational conveniences.  We use for loops primarily for definite looping,
and we use while loops primarily for indefinite looping; the syntax of each is set up to help create these patterns easily.  
However, computationally they are equivalent in their capabilities.
Anything we can do with a for loop, we can do with a while loop as well, and vice versa.
This means we can do definite loops with while ( but a for loop would be more convenient ). We can also do indefinite looping with a for loop (but
a while would be easier).  It is a bit more common to use a while loop for definite looping than it is to use a for loop for indefinite.
We will see this in the problems in this folder.
As with for loops we will write a boolean comparison expression to answer the question "should we execute the loop body another time?" ; this expression will usually examine the variables being used in the loop body.
To complete this problem, type in this JavaScript program (remember to use the myMain function format for style points):
  var x = 1; // loop index varible
  while ( x This is a definite loop; it is set up to execute the loop body 5 times. Note that the loop index variable (x) we had to set up and 
increment ourselves.  We started x at 1, and stopped when it became larger than 5. In a for loop, this bookkeeping is done automatically for us.
For this while loop, we print the square of the index variable each time we execute the loop body.  Thus, the output is a sequence of 
the squares of the first 5 positive integers.

Write a program that asks the user to input numbers repeatedly, sums up all the user inputs and prints the final sum.Stop looping when the use gives a 0 as the input number.
 
For now, we will go back to assuming that the user can properly type good numbers... so there is no need to validate the input.  
This way we can concentrate on learning the loop structure.
Most of the time we will use while loops for indefinite repetitions, when we need to repeat a block of code 
an unknown number of times.  
In an indefinite loop, we don't know a priori the specific number of loop iterations that will be needed.
One common pattern it to ask the user for some input inside the loop body and
keep looping until the user gives us some special "flag" value that signals us to stop looping.  This means
the boolean condition that controls the loop will be examining the user input variable and checking for the
special flag value.
Here, the stop flag is the number value 0. If the user gives 0 as the very first input, let's assume the sum will also be 0.  
Technically, in this case there have been no numbers to add, so there would be no sum to report, but we will define it as 0 as
a special case.  Many programs have one or more such special cases.
Style: Use a while loop.  Use no for loops.

Write a program that asks the user to input a positive integer 120 or smaller.  Validate the input to make sure it is a number, that it is in range, and thatit is an integer. If any validation fails print "bad" and end execution.

Let's see one significant example of using while loops to do definite looping. After that we will concentrate on using them
for indefinite looping. 
As noted before, a for loop is usually a better choice for definite looping, but we want to illustrate that while loops can also do it.... 
and illustrate how doing all the loop index bookkeeping manually is more cumbersome 
and error prone than letting a for loop do it automatically.
Go to the program "Format checking: Factorial 2" in module "Input validation" and reload your working code for that problem.  Now we will
change the for-loop to a while-loop and see that the program produces the same functional behavior.
To do this we will need to directly declare a variable to use as loop index, and initialize it to 1 (since we are accumulating
via multiplication).  We need to remember to put an increment of that variable as the last statement in the while loop body.
Finally, we need to write a boolean comparison to use as the condition that determines if we repeat the loop body another time.
Style: Use a while loop. Do not use any for loops.

 If it is not, print "bad expo" and end execution.

Write a program that asks the user to input numbers repeatedly, sums up all the user inputs and prints the final sum.Stop looping when the use gives a 0 as the input number.
 
This is the same program we just wrote, but this time we are going to structure the while loop a little differently We are going to use a common "break out" pattern that allows 
us to have one prompt line rather than two. Here we will specifically set up an "infinite" loop and put a special if-then statement in the 
body that will decide if it is time to jump out of the loop (thereby ending it).  Until that condition is met, the loop will
continue to go back and repeat the loop body again.
An "infinite" while has this form:
  while (true) {
     // loop body code...
     // conditional... should we break out?
    //  code ...
  }
Since the boolean expression "true" will never evaluate to false, this loop will never stop repeating... unless we jump out of it to whatever follows... unless we "break" out.
Let's revisit the previous loop where we summed inputs from the user. This time we will use the break statement
to end the loop when the flag (0 from the user) is seen.  It looks like this:
  if ( num === 0 ) { break; }  // if you leave this out your browser will wedge
This goes inside the while, right after asking the user for input.  The "break" makes the program stop
the loop and continue executing at the statement after the closing " } " for the while loop.
Annoyance notes: As you will probably discover, there is a small danger in using an "infinte" loop with the break-out pattern.
"Infinite" means something.  It means that if you do not break out, then the loop will never stop repeating.
You will experience this as your browser wedging... locking up... as the JavaScript engine runs endlessly and consumes all the browser horsepower.
How can you fail to break out?  You might get the condition logic wrong and write a boolean expression that will not evaluate to true and so will not trigger the "break".
You might forget to update the user input, so the loop keeps testing the first input and never gets more.
There are several ways to mess it up.  Once you do it a few times you will get accustomed to checking carefully.
Even in while loops that are not the infinite form... that have some condition like ( k Style: Use a while loop.  Use no for loops.

Write a program that will add up consecutive integers starting at 1 and print out the integer that causes the sum to go over 1000 when it is added in.  Then print out the sum in a second alert statement.
 
In this program, we are not stopping after a set number of repetitions (like in a for loop) and we are not stopping when the user signals to end.
Rather, we will end the loop when some condition on the program data becomes true.  In this case, we will watch an accumulator variable (the sum)
to see when it's value exceeds some limit (1000).
For example, let's say we wanted to do this problem using 12 rather than 1000 as our sum to watch for.
We are going to sum up 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, etc. until our sum becomes larger than 12. 
We start with 1, add it in and get sum of 1 (not larger than 12)
then add 2 to get sum of 3 (not larger than 12)
then add in 3 to get sum of 6 (not larger than 12)
then add in 4 to get sum of 10 (not larger than 12)
then add in 5 to get sum of 15 (... IS larger than 12 so stop summing / looping) 

then print 5 (the number that when added in made the sum go over 12) 
then print 15 (the sum when we stopped).
You must do this with a while loop.  
You can end the loop with whatever method you prefer.
You will need to set up a counter variable to use for generating the sequence of integers that you are summing.
You will need an accumulator variable for the sum.
Style: Use a while loop.  Use no for loops.  There is no user input, so we won't need data validation.

Write a program that will repeatedly ask the user for a number and print the cube of that number (truncated to 4 decimal places).If the user gives 0 as input, exit the loop.
 
We will do input validation for this program.

First validate the input to make sure the user gives something numeric; if the data is not a number, print the error message "error, try again"
and repeat the loop so that the user is asked to input again.
If the user gives a good numeric data value, then check it for 0, which will make the loop stop repeating.
Then validate the number to be sure it is not negative; if it is negative print "negative, try again" and repeat the loop so that the user is asked to input again.
Finally, if the input is a valid non-negative number, cube the number, truncate it to 4 decimal places, and print the result.  
Use Math.floor to do the truncating, since we are validating that the input number is non-negative.
Please note the special case of the user giving 0 as the very first number.  In this case, your program should produce no output.
Remember to test your program on non-integer numbers to make sure it is truncating correctly. 
For example, 12.34567 should produce 1881.6723 and 0.0654321 should produce 0.0002 as output.

Write a program that asks the user to input a number between 0 and 1 (including 0, excluding 1).Then repeatedly square the number, saving it back into itself (like the accumulator pattern).
Stop when the value becomes smaller that 0.0001. Print out how many squarings it took to get below that tolerance.
 
In this program we will use a while loop to continually square a fractional number until it comes "close to" zero.  We define "close to" to be
smaller than 0.0001, so not really 0 but "close enough" for our purposes.  Remember that when we square a number between 0 and 1,
the square is smaller than the number we squared.  For example, 0.5 * 0.5 is 0.25.  Then 0.25 * 0.25 is 0.0625.
Note that if the user gives a number that is less than the tolerance (less than 0.0001) then we do not square at all... we simply stop and report that we
did 0 squarings.
Here is some sample execution data:
user input: 0.25                                   0th squaring, 0.25 is larger that the tolerance 0.0001
0.25 * 0.25               is 0.0625                1st squaring,  0.0625 is larger than the tolerance 0.0001
0.0625 * 0.0625           is 0.00390625            2nd squaring, 0.00390625 is larger than the tolerance 0.0001
0.00390625 * 0.00390625   is 0.0000152587890625    3rd squaring, 0.0000152587890625 is SMALLER than the tolerance 0.0001 
so we are done
it went smaller than .0001 with the 3 squaring so we print 3
user input: 0
since this is already less than the tolerance 0.00001 we stop immediately, and do no squarings so we print 0
user input: 0.0000001
since this is already less than the tolerance 0.00001 we stop immediately, and do no squarings so we print 0
This further illustrates indefinite looping, since we have no idea in advance how many times we will have to square the number before 
it gets to our "near zero" threshold.  So we will use a while loop that squares, checks for "near zero", and repeats if needed.

Write a program that asks the user to input numbers repeatedly, sums up all the user inputs and prints the final sum.Stop looping when the use gives the character "q" as input.
 
Now let's combine the earlier summing inputs program with some validation.  We will base this program on the one we just wrote, and make a change or two.
One change is in the stopping signal.  Here we will use a string (character 'q') as our stop signal rather than the number 0 as before.
This time, when we prompt the user and get some input, we will have two tests to perform before we can do summation/accumulation.
First we must check the input string to see if it is the special "q" signal to stop looping and end the program.
If it is not "q", then we validate that input to make sure it is a number (and not some string other than "q").
If it is not a number, we print the error message "non numeric, try again" and then
make the loop go around again so the user is asked again for another input.  In this way, nothing is summed into the accumulator if the input is not a number;
If the input is a valid number, we add it to the sum we are accumulating..
To make a loop go on to the next iteration and go again, use the continue statement.  This is bit like "break", but
it ends the current loop body only; break ends the entire loop. The continue essentially says "let's skip the rest of this loop body
and go back around again".  If the user gives a non-number we don't want to execute the rest of the body; we want to repeat the
request for input and let the user try again.  This is the beginnings of a validation strategy that is a little better than printing "bad" and ending execution.
We will develop this "re-ask the user" strategy more fully in a later module.
Testing notes: Remember that the numbers the user gives can be negative... there is nothing in the specifications that requires positive input.
Try testing with a sequence of negative and positive numbers to see that the sum is happening as it should.  The number 0 is also
valid input and should not change the sum.
Style: Use a while loop.  Use no for loops.

Style:Use myMain format, as always.  Use no global variables.  
Also, use the appropriate loops for the various situations needing loops.
Declare and use at least two functions other than myMain (3 functions total or more).

Scope 
"Scope" is the term we use for the parts of a program in which a particular declared variable is visible (useable).  "Scope rules" are the decision procedures 
that allow us to determine what storage location in memory is denoted when we see a variable name in our code.  
In other words, when you see a variable used in an expression,  you can decide which "var" declaration is being used. 
It is possible, for example, to have several lines that look like "var x ;" in your code.   
When we see something like  "x = 5 ;" we need to know which of the several "var x ;" lines is the variable being referenced in the expression.
In JavaScript we have two main scopes: global, and local. 
Global scope is the collection of variables and names (function names) declared outside of all function definitions.
We can have code statements at the global level, and
we can have variable declarations at the global level. A global variable can be seen and used inside any function, as well
as in code at the global level.
Local scope is the collection of variables and names declared inside a function definition (this includes the parameters).
A local variable can be seen and used by any code that is inside the function it is declared in, but it is invisible (undefined) 
in code that is global, or inside other function declarations.
We are not going to use global code in most of our programs.  For these in this section, where we are specifically learning about
global vs. local, we will write and use some.
To complete this overview, type in and run this program:
"use strict"; 

var gx = 5; // global var declaration

function myMain() {
  alert( gx ); // use of global var from inside local function scope
}

alert(gx);  // use of global var from global scope
myMain();
Here the variable "gx" is in the global scope (we say "gx is a global variable") because it is declared not inside any function.
Since it is global, we can use it inside any function.  Hence, we can print our its value from inside of myMain.  We can also print its value
at the global level.  
Note also that the name "myMain" is also a global name; this is why the call to myMain is outside any function as well.
That call is a global code statement.  For most of our programs, that is the only global executable statement we will have.
In this code, we have two global executable statements: the alert, and then the call to myMain.

Let's modify the previous program that uses a global variable to show how a local variable with the same name can hide the global variable.Write a program that has function myMain() and function helper().
In myMain ask the user to input a number (no need to validate) and assign that number to a global variable "num".
Call function helper() and then print the value of global variable "num" squared.
Don't submit the program yet... just run it and see that it behaves like the one we did just before this.  It *is* the one we just did.
The global variable "num" can be seen and used inside the helper function.
Now for the win... inside function helper
 declare a local variable "num". Assign to the local num the value 5,
right before the code you already have to square variable num and return.  Now no matter what value the user gives as input, the program
produces 25 as output; the local "num" has a 5 in it, and that local hides the global "num" containing the user's input value.
This program shows that when a function has a declared local variable with the same name as a global variable,
the global variable is not visible inside the function.  No assignment to the local variable will change the global. No reference to the
local name can retrieve the value from the global storage location.
Scope Rules: The rules that allow us to determine what storage location (var declaration) matches some used of a variable (an expression or assignment) are called scope rules.  In JavaScript,  these are the rules.  
JavaScript Scope RulesWhen a name is encountered (variable or function), to find the declaration that it references

1) look inside the function that the name is used in, to see if there is a local declaration for the name 
    (var declaration, function declaration, parameter); if there is one locally, then that is the correct declaration

2) if there is nothing local, then look globally for a declaration matching the name (either a global variable declaration, 
    or a function declaration)

3) if there is no local declaration for the name, and no global declaration, then the name is undeclared; 
    nothing declared inside one function is visible inside some other function

looks locally in the function where the name is used, and then globally.  Use of a name in one function cannot refer to storage
created inside another function.
When we need to communicate values from one function to another , we do it  with parameter passing (and the return statement).

This exercise shows that a global variable can be read and written in all functions (as long as there is no

with the same name that hides the global variable.

Write a program to generate 1,000,000 random numbers between 0 and 100 (include 0, exclude 100) and compute the average.  Print the average rounded to the nearest integer.
 
We want to make sure the random numbers are floating point values (in other words, don't convert the output from the scaled Math.random to
integer).  We are not converting to integer until after the average is taken.
Note that we are rounding the final average for output (not truncating).
For thought: given the uniform distribution, what do you think the average should be for a big pile of random numbers between 0 and 100?

Write a program that will generate a single random number between 0 and 50 (but never quite being 50) and print it. 
Math.random produces numbers in the range [0,1).  Here we need numbers in an expanded range [0,50), with the lower end still 
at 0. We want the distribution to remain uniform.  So to do this, we can simply generate a random number and multiply
it by a factor that will expand the range upward.  The obvious factor (in this case) is 50.  All numbers generated 
by Math.random are then used as a percentage, telling how far into the range [0,50) to go to get the
final random output.
Let's reason about the range that results after this scaling.  Since Math.random might generate a 0, and since 0*50 is zero, the scaling might also generate 0 (as we wish).  Since Math.random with almost (but not quite) generate a 1, the scaling will generate (almost 1)*50, or almost but not quite 50 (as we wish).
One last comment... mathematically, we are talking about numbers with precision after the decimal point here (floating point, or real number values).  We are not trying to generate random integers in this program.  We will do that in later programs.

Write a program that will generate a single random integer between 0 and 100 (including both) and print it. Then generate a single random integer between 5 and 25 (including both) and print it.
 
This problem illustrates two new capabilities: generating random integers, and moving the lower range up from 0. 
For integers, we will use Math.floor to take a random real number and make it integer. Note the twist here... the integer range is [0,100], meaning we want to include the upper end (100). Since Math.random will never generate exactly 1, if we scale the range by multiplying by 100, we will never quite get 100 and then Math.floor will back that down to the integer 99. So if we want 100 as possible output, we must scale to (almost) 101 and let Math.floor truncate to 100.
For the second output, we note that we need to shift the range up 5 from 0. The high end of the range we want is 25, so if we generate a number between 0 and 20, then add 5 we get a range of 5 to 25. So we can scale the range by multiplying the output of Math.random, and we can shift the range by adding to the result of Math.random (or the result of Math.floor(scaled random).

Write a program that will go through an array item-by-item, from the beginning, and print each element. 
We will create an array containing the first 10 prime numbers (with 2 being the first prime).
Do this with a variable declaration and a array literal to initialize that variable.
Needing to access every element in an array, systemaically, is a very common and heavily used programming pattern.  We use a for loop to dom it, as we know the size of the array (we know
exactly how many elements we need to access).  Inside the for loop body, we handle one element, and we use the loop index variable to designate which array slot number
we are dealing with each iteration.
To print the array elements, use a for loop that runs from 0 up to (but not including) the length
of the array.  This means if the array length is 10, then the for loop runs from 0 to 9.
However, we will use the length expression in loop control -- rather than the literal 9, or 10 -- since that is more general.
Then in the loop body, we use the loop index variable as the expression in the subscript square brackets to get the value stored in the array slot.

Write a program that will print out the average of the first 10 primes (with 2 as first prime). 
We are going to use an array to do this.  As in an earlier problem, we will first
create an array that contains the first 10 primes.
Then we will systematically access every element in the array, from slot 0 to the last,
and sum up all the values stored in the array.  This will be the same as an accumulator pattern we
have used many times before.
Once we have the sum, and the for loop ends, we compute the average by dividing the sum by the number of
elements we summed up.  We will use the length of the array to divide (i.e.: we do not simply divide by the constant 10).

Write a program that will load user inputs into an array for internal storage; the user will signal end of input with a 0. Print the length of the array, the first array element, and the last array element with 3 separate alerts.

and then access those inputs later by access the array slots they were stored into.
Write a program that will loop repeatedly (indefinite looping... use a while loop and we will make it an "infinite" loop with break-out) asking the user to input a number (no need to validate). 
An input of 0 will end the loop. Store each number into an array in sequential slots. Do not store the terminating 0 into the array.
Since this is a while loop, we will have to set up a counter to keep track of loop body executions.  We will used this counter as the array index indicator... the number of the array slot into which
the user input will be stored.  Since arrays start at index 0, we will start the counter at 0.
When a user input is received, we must first check it for the 0 stop signal, and break out if we get that.
If the input is not the stop signal, we then assign the number to the array at the slot given by out counter.
After that, we increment the counter (and the loop will repeat).
Note that by checking for 0 first in the loop body, we do not end up assigning that 0 into an array slot.
Once we end the loop (break out on 0 input), we do the requested output.
We first print the length of the array; we use the length property that all arrays have to get that. If the user has given 12 inputs (let's assume the array variable is "arr") then
the expression " arr.length " will evaluate to 12.
We have to remember that array slot numbers start at 0; this means the 1st element stored in the array is found at slot 0, and the last element (by the same reasoning) is
found in slot " arr.length-1 ".

Write a program to fill an array with numbers from the user (0 ends the input). After all inputs have been obtained and stored, find the largest element in the array and print out that value; in a separate alert, print out the slot number that the
largest value is stored in.
 
A while-loop is appropriate for filling the array with user inputs; this is an indeterminate situation, 
since we do not know a priori how many data values the user will want to input.
We will not validate input data for this program; we will assume the user gives input that looks like valid numbers.
To find the largest element stored in the array after it is filled, we will need another loop to examine every element
systematically. This second loop is not nested in the body of the first one, but outside of it, and after it.
A for-loop is appropriate for this second loop, since we know exactly how long the array is and we need to examine each element.
When the user gives a 0 as input, signaling to stop, do not stored the 0 into the array.
Looking for the largest uses a common programming pattern, one where we need to compute some quantity
and must examine every array element in order to do so.  In this case, we want to find the value that
is largest.  We are going to keep a separate variable to hold that value (much like an accumulator or counter is a separate variable).
Let's call that variable "biggestSoFar" and we will think of it as holding the value that is (of the array elements examined so far) the largest.
We will start it with some very small number... something that will be exceeded by the very first array element we examine (the one in slot 0).
Then we will compare the next element in the array to the largest, and everytime we find an array element that is
larger, we save the new "biggest" value.
When we have examined all array elements then "biggestSoFar" is biggest of all the array values.
To keep track of the slot number that the biggest value is stored in, we keep a second variable to hold an integer (like, say, "slotNum").  Everytime we
find a new "biggest", we copy the slot number it is stored in into the variable "slotNum".
Output format: Let's say the user gives us an array of inputs and the largest number is 101, stored in array slot 7.  The output will look this way:
value: 101
slot: 7

Write a program to fill an array with numbers from the user (0 ends the input).Then ask the user for a single number.  No need to validate any of this input.  
Print "found it!" if the array contains this number and print "nope, not there" if it does not.
 
 Build this one off the previous program.  The user input section that loads the array will be the same.
We will alter the for-loop that does the searching.  In particular, we will now ask the user for a single number (the "target" of our search), and then
as we go through the for loop we will ask if each element we encounter is equal to the target.
Searching large data collections (many hundreds of thousands of items) in this way can be inefficient.  There are better ways
than arrays to organize data collections for many problems.  These better organizations allow us to find items more rapidly by 
not forcing us to examine every item in most cases.  As an example... if all the items in the array were in sorted order, and we were looking
for some specific number value (like, say, 100), then as soon as I came to an array item that was larger than 100, I would know that all the
rest of the values are not the one i seek.  I could then end my search early, and announce "nope, not there" without looking at every element.
The study of how to organize, build, sort, and search data collection for efficient problem solution is what the "Data Structures" and "Analysis
of Algorithms" classes in our curriculum are all about.  Once we learn some basic programming well, we then turn to learning efficient programming.

Write a program that accepts words (input strings) from the user and stores each string into an array element.  An input of "done" will stop the input loop.After all input is received, print out all array elements that alphabetically come after the word "javascript".
 
In this problem we will see that arrays can store string data as well as the numbers we have used up to now.
Actually, arrays can store objects as well, but they is for later programs.  Since we are on the topic of what we can store into an array slot, let me
remind you that arrays do not have to be homogeneous.  Many -- perhaps most -- of our programs so far have been using arrays containing all number, for example.
An array can be heterogeneous -- it can contain a mix of data types as data values.  The array is the overview of the first array module was this way:
   var data = [ 7, "smith", -4.25, true ] ;  // contains number, string, and boolean data values in one array
Now, in this program, we will use a homogeneous array of string data. Your previous program is a good base to start with, and we will then alter it to deal with strings.
There is no real change needed in the indefinite while loop that gets user input, except we will not call function "Number" to convert the text input.
We request a single string from the user (the search target) and also do not covert that... we leave it as text data.
The main change we need is in the searching loop.  In the previous program, if we found the target we stopped looping, as all we needed to know was
if the item was there or not.  In this search loop, we will not stop once we find a word that comes after "javascript"; rather we must keep on searching
the following array elements, to the end, as there can be more than one word that matches our search criterion.
We also will be using the ">" operator to search, rather than equality.  We don't want a match for "javascript", we want to know if a word is beyond that
in alphabetic order.  Each time we find a word that is beyond the target, we print that word.

Write a program that will nsert a new element (input from the user) into an array of values that are in numerical order (smallest to largest).The program will move array elements around, to make room for a new element to be placed in the proper place in the ordered sequence.  See details following.
 
Commonly, when using arrays, we will need to move values stored in array slots around, from one slot to another.
We do this, for example, when sorting elements into order.  We start out with the elements in one order, and end up shuffling the values
around from slot to slot until we get a new order that meets our criteria.
In this program, we are seeing how this is done.  We start with an array containing some numbers in order, and we get a new number from the user.
We then will look at each item stored in the array to find the two array elements that the
new number belongs between (in numeric order).  We "slide" the remaining array elements to higher slots, opening up a "hole" in the array
so there is then a slot that is free... so there is room to put the new number into the array in proper order.
Ever been to concert, and someone shows up at your row and the person next to you says "can you all move down one so this person can sit here next to me" ?
Well that is what we are doing here... with array slots being like seats in the row.
Detailed specifications: Write a program that declares an array and initializes it with 0, 20, 30, 50, 70, 110, 130, 170, 190,
230, and 290 (the first 10 primes * 10); also put in 1000 as the last element. 
Print the length of the array.
Then ask the user to input a positive number that is less that 1000 (no need to validate). Insert the number into the array at the proper location so that all current elements remain in the array and the small-to-large order is maintained. 
When done print all elements in the array from slot 0 up, one alert per element.
Then print the length of the array.
To do this you will need to pass through the array comparing the elements in the slots
to the number the user gave.  When you find two slot numbers that have elements 
that straddle the value being inserted, you will have to "shove up" the elements 
in the higher end of the array.  This means moving the last element to a slot one higher, then
moving the next-to-last into the slot that was the last, etc.
Note that by printing the length of the array, before and after, you see that inserting the new element makes the array longer by one.

Write a program to create an array that has 1001 slots (index 0 to 1000) .  In each array slot store the value of a function (defined following)computed on the number that is the slot number. Using your completed array, print (in separate alerts)
the value in slot 8, the value in slot 61, the value in slot 707, and the value in slot 999.
 
This program is similar to the VID brick we did called "Even numbers".
Here we want to be able to store values for 0 to 1000, so the array has to contain 1001 elements (slots 0 to 1000).
As we go systematically through the array from slot 0 to slot 1000, for each slot i we compute the function and then store that result
into the array at slot i.
The function: For each slot number n, compute n cubed, then take the 4th root of that, and then truncate the result to 10 decimal places.
For example, in array slot 5, we will store this:
trunc10 ( Math.pow( 5*5*5, 0.25 ) )     which is 3.343701524
where trunc10 is a function you write that truncates a number to 10 decimal places. Math.pow ( num, 0.25 ) takes the 4th root (raises num to the 1/4th power), 
and the 4th root is also the same as taking the square root twice in succession.
This kind of data structure, and usage, is often called a lookup table.  The specific function we are computing here
(4th root of a number cubed) is not particularly difficult, but some functions can be complicated to compute (expensive in time 
or memory used) so when we know we will need to compute those values a lot, it can be more efficient to compute a range of them
in advance and same the values in an array, where they can be looked up very quickly (more quickly that it would take to re-compute the
function).
Lookup tables are used in  CPU chip in your computer, for example, to make floating point arithmetic faster.

Using Bubble Up (which you wrote in a previous module), implement Bubble Sort

easy one to program.  However, bubble sort is very inefficient and is used almost exclusively as a programming

We wrote "Bubble Up" in a previous module. It takes the largest element in an array

at a time with separate alerts.
When done you will have 3 functions: myMain, bubbleUp, and bubbleSort.

Write a program that creates a function value that is not bound to a name, and then bind that anonymous function value to a global name. 
A function value with no name bound to it is called "anonymous".  An anonymous function can still be defined and later bound to a name (saved for later execution).
In this problem we illustrate function as first class values by creating a function with no name (an anonymous function)
and then "binding" that function value to a name with "=" assignment.
To create an anonymous function value, we use the "function" keyword as we are accustomed to doing, but we do not put a name
after the keyword.  We do create an argument list (in parentheses) and the code body (in curly braces).
It is identical to defining a named function except we do not give it a name.
Here is an example (using the code from the previously defined named function "double"):
function ( n ) {  return 2*n; }
Again, this is a function value... it is the same thing for type "function" as writing the number value "5" is for type "number".
It is valid JavaScript, and we must now decide what we wish to do with this value.  In this program we will take that
function value, and bind it to a global name using assignment.  In the next program, we will see how to execute that
function value without ever naming it.
Details. First at the global level create an anonymous function value using the previous code for "double" with one argument (as shown
in the previous pre-format box).  Assign that anonymous function to the global variable "double" using assignment.
Then define the global function (myMain) as we usually do.  Inside myMain, call double(5) and print the returned result.
Notes. This program illustrates that the "normal" way of defining functions -- using the "function" keyword and a name for the function --
is actually a shorthand notation for doing what we are doing here... creating a nameless function value, and then binding it to a global name.
Binding it to a global name is what makes us able to run the function from within our other functions.
Also, we must be careful to get our code in the right order.  Since we are explicitly creating a global variable (the name for the function) we
must do that declaration and binding before we call myMain.  If we do not, when myMain runs and tried to call the function bound to 
the name "double", that global variable will not yet have been declared.  So do things in this order: 
 declare the global variable "double" and assign a function to it   declare function myMain , that calls "double" call myMain to kick it all off Relevance to objects.We will be (in the next module) putting functions inside objects (we call them "methods" for historical reasons).  
To put a function into an object, we will be using this form of definition... creating an anonymous function value and then
binding it to a field name inside the object.

Write a program that creates a function value that is not bound to a name, and then executes that anonymous function. 
In this problem we illustrate function as first class values by creating a function with no name (an anonymous function)
and executing it without binding it to a name.  This is advanced capability of JavaScript, and we are just doing it here to make
you familiar with the fact that is can be done.  We will not be using this capability in future program in this course.
In professional JavaScript programs, such as code for large websites, this 
technique is used a great deal.  It is also a characteristic of languages that are called 
"functional languages".
For this program, we wont even need a myMain function.
At the global level create an anonymous function value (using the previous code for "double" with one argument).
After defining the value, supply an argument of 5 to it and execute it.  
Print the returned result.
Details.What syntax shall we use to cause a function with no name to execute?  And how shall we pass it the argument 5 ?
Let's consider how we call a named function.
First we write the name, then we put the argument(s) in parentheses after the name.  For example, to run the "double" function we did this:
var result = double ( 5 );
What actually happens in this case is the function value bound to the name "double" is retrieved and executed on the arguments in the parenthesized list.
When we have the function value directly, we have no need to evaluate a name to find it.  So we will just write out the value, and put a parenthesized list after the
function value.  That will make the function value execute on the arguments in the parenthesized list:
var result = ( function ( n ) { return 2*n; } ) ( 5 ) ;
Then the variable "result" will contain the value returned by the execution of the function on the argument 5; that is, the variable result will contain 10.
We can then alert the value stored in "result" .

Write a program that uses a recursive function to compute and print out the factorial of a positive integer N. 
As noted in the overview, recursion is a very useful programming technique in which a function calls itself (re-cursion means re-occurring).
A function that calls itself is called a recursive function.
Earlier we computed the factorial of a number by looping and using an accumulator.
Now we will solve the same problem recursively.
To do this we remember the definition of factorial from math class:
N!  is  N * (N-1) * (N-2) * ... * (3) * (2) * (1)

note that (N-1) * (N-2) * ... (3) * (2) * (1)   by this pattern is (N-1)!

so N!  =  N * (N-1)!
So a function to compute N! can call itself to compute (N-1)! and then multiply the result by N to get N!
We will use the math equation for factorial as a guide to writing the code.
For a base case, we will use factorial of 1... which is defined to be 1.  The base case will test the parameter for value 1, and simply return 1.
Then the recursive case will be for all other values of the parameter, and it will call factorial recursively, a pass in the parameter less 1 (a smaller number to compute factorial of).
When that returns, the result is multiplied by the parameter and returned.
Write a myMain function that will ask the user to input an integer larger than 0 (no need to validate) and will then print out the result of calling the recursive factorial 
function on that integer.
Computer Science notes:We are not validating user input... but what might happen if the user in not cooperative?
For instance, what will happen if the user gives the integer 0 as input?
Try mentally executing the code on 0... then try running it with 0 as input.

When the function "summer" returns a value, print out that value.
We are doing this sequence summing by writing and calling a recursive function named "summer".
Summer will take one argument, and return the sum of all integers from 1 to that argument.
As with all recursive functions, we will get the work done in summer by writing first a base case: if the parameter value is 1, then return 1 as the sum of integers from 1 to 1.
The recursive case will then be for all values of the parameter larger than 1.  FIrst we will call summer recursively and pass it the argument less 1 (this is summing a smaller
problem).  Then when that call returns, we take the sum sent back and add to it the parameter value.  We return that new sum as the result of the function.
Example executions:positive integer?  4
10         // this is because 4+3+2+1 is 10
positive integer? 1
1      // base case, no recursion needed
positive integer? 11
